really know who those people are wandering about outside
your window at night?
Welcome to the real world, Homewood. Crime is not a

like for the sake of security? Or should a permanent staff,
one which could recognize the students and prevent
needless hassles, be installed?

They're having a party
Sexism strikes again! In the golden tradition of last
year's Beta ad ("Wanna Ball?"), Phi Gamma Delta seems to
be out to set a new record as the fastest fraternity to
exhibit blatant sexism.
Most students, no doubt, have not seen their poster, and
it is just! as well. Laughably laid out, poorly copied and
amateurishly written, it smacks of high school liocker room
humor, not quite what ,one could,expect of Hopkins. It is a
crude ad, appealling to crude people, and one can only
wonder wh'at'sort of student Fiji hopes to attract.
None the less, the offense has been taken, and what is
most annoying is that it seems to be a consistent offense.
Why is it that the Frats feel a need to resort to such levels
of inducement? Is it because Frats, like other exclusionist
societies, are basically oppressive and chauvinistic? One can
only look at their marvelous heritage of hazings and wonder
how such a barbarous pastime ever gained popularity..
Currently, it seems that the goal of most fraternities is to
provide a vehicle for students to get together and get drunk
or high(or both).
An admirable pursuit, indeed.
In fairness, though, one must admit that it is only the
few whoimake the many look bad, and certainly there are
many frat houses whose activities are both egalitarian and
commendable. But one must ask .if fraternities are still
relevant in the seventies, or if they merely reflect society's
yearning for the placidity of the fifties, when sexism, racism
and sectarianism was looked upon as "good, clean fun."

It was Edmund Burke who once said that
the age of chivalry had gone, and it seems that one of
calculators and economists has succeeded.
Every Wednesday night, however, chivalry returns to
the Johns Hopkins University campus when the SCA, or
Society for Creative Anachronisms, meets to do battle
with those having little faith or interest in the Middle
Ages.
To most, the main attraction would have to be the
broadswordfighting exhibition given by the more
experienced members of the Society. Though fighting
with mock swords and wooden shileds, the combatants
flail away at each other with unbounded enthusiasm. The
duels aren't all fun and games. A blow from one of those
hard wood swords, which are weighted to accurately
simulate a real sword, delivered by an experienced hand,
can leave a painful bruise. (I know -- I have several of
them already).
But if one isn't particularly interested in fighting with
sword and shield (though the impulse to don armor and
helmet is almost_ irresistible), one can always try being a
magician, juggler, court jester, bard, squire, alchemist,
yeoman, or even a simple peasant -- if you like tilling soil.
In fact, the SCA encourages people to join who are
interested in most anything about the Middle Ages. If one
has ever been thinking about the days when bold gents
and fair ladies made their own music, candles, and
entertainment, when feasts were held to rouse the spirit
and empty the mead tankard, this is the clu b to join.
Why do people from our modern technological society
wish to go back in time to the days of King Arthur or
Henry VIII? After all, the common man of today lives
better than the richest King ever did a thousand years ago.
What is it about the Middle Ages that stirs the imagination
of the members to actually attempt to simulate the days
of yore?
The answers may surprise you: they surprised me. The
SCA is not attempting to simulate the Dark Ages, which is
an ominous and revealing title to one of our most
misunderstood historical ages, but is, rather, trying to
show the Middle Ages as they should have been. As one
member put it,"We don't want to reinstitute plague."
The Dark Ages was a time of disease and war, a period
of both religious and political rigidity. These facets of the

Middle Ages arc remembered all too well by the textbook
readers. What the SCA presents is the other side of the
gold piece: the music, arts, dancing, literature, poetry,
chivalry, feasts, jousts, and folklore of the years from 700
AD to roughly 1650 AD. Individual creativity, something
today 's industrialized common man sadly lacks,
flourished during the years of lords and castles, and it is
this essence of creativity which the SCA wishes to capture
and expand upon.
In case the reader should think that the SCA is a crew
of hopeless romantics centered in the Baltimore area, it
should be known that the SCA is a nationwide one.
holding feasts, jousts, and other events periodically
throughout the year. Two Kingdoms, the Eastern
Kingdom and the Western Kingdom, compete between
themselves for the lost glory of nights in shining armor
winning damsels in distress. Sadly, there are no dragons
left to fight on this world.
In a sense, however, all SCA members are.incurably in
love with the Age of Chivalry. A member gets to choose
his or her own name, title, family history, etc. -- the only
limit being that one cannot be named after a real person
or fictionalized character without permission, which is
slightly difficult in the former case. For those Tolkien,
Moorcock, or other fantasy readers, this is your chance to
become a part of the fantasy you always hoped you could
act out but never dared.
If you insist on being a fighting man or woman,armor
is something of a problem. There are strict rules and
regulations as to what one can wear or must wear, set by
the SCA higher echelons. To engage the Black Knight, I
had to don armor which barely fit, a helm which almost
tore off my ears, hockey gloves for fist barding, elbow
pads‘ which constantly fell off, and a leather knee pad
which really was meant to be a thigh pad. The only
advantages my opponent had were superior training,
physique, and armor.. I won't bore you with the trivial
details of how the fight progressed: suffice it to say that I
am burning with desire to avenge my honor...
Therefore, if you can peel yourself away from studying
for a knight, come an,d see the SCA on _either the
Freshmen Quad or the field in front of Garland. Lose
yourself to a time of honour and chivalry, of jousting and
jesting, of good fun.

It was Edmund Burke who once said that
the age of chivalry had gone, and it seems that one of
calculators and economists has succeeded.
Every Wednesday night, however, chivalry returns to
the Johns Hopkins University campus when the SCA, or
Society for Creative Anachronisms, meets to do battle
with those having little faith or interest in the Middle
Ages.
To most, the main attraction would have to be the
broadswordfighting exhibition given by the more
experienced members of the Society. Though fighting
with mock swords and wooden shileds, the combatants
flail away at each other with unbounded enthusiasm. The
duels aren't all fun and games. A blow from one of those
hard wood swords, which are weighted to accurately
simulate a real sword, delivered by an experienced hand,
can leave a painful bruise. (I know -- I have several of
them already).
But if one isn't particularly interested in fighting with
sword and shield (though the impulse to don armor and
helmet is almost_ irresistible), one can always try being a
magician, juggler, court jester, bard, squire, alchemist,
yeoman, or even a simple peasant -- if you like tilling soil.
In fact, the SCA encourages people to join who are
interested in most anything about the Middle Ages. If one
has ever been thinking about the days when bold gents
and fair ladies made their own music, candles, and
entertainment, when feasts were held to rouse the spirit
and empty the mead tankard, this is the clu b to join.
Why do people from our modern technological society
wish to go back in time to the days of King Arthur or
Henry VIII? After all, the common man of today lives
better than the richest King ever did a thousand years ago.
What is it about the Middle Ages that stirs the imagination
of the members to actually attempt to simulate the days
of yore?
The answers may surprise you: they surprised me. The
SCA is not attempting to simulate the Dark Ages, which is
an ominous and revealing title to one of our most
misunderstood historical ages, but is, rather, trying to
show the Middle Ages as they should have been. As one
member put it,"We don't want to reinstitute plague."
The Dark Ages was a time of disease and war, a period
of both religious and political rigidity. These facets of the

Middle Ages arc remembered all too well by the textbook
readers. What the SCA presents is the other side of the
gold piece: the music, arts, dancing, literature, poetry,
chivalry, feasts, jousts, and folklore of the years from 700
AD to roughly 1650 AD. Individual creativity, something
today 's industrialized common man sadly lacks,
flourished during the years of lords and castles, and it is
this essence of creativity which the SCA wishes to capture
and expand upon.
In case the reader should think that the SCA is a crew
of hopeless romantics centered in the Baltimore area, it
should be known that the SCA is a nationwide one.
holding feasts, jousts, and other events periodically
throughout the year. Two Kingdoms, the Eastern
Kingdom and the Western Kingdom, compete between
themselves for the lost glory of nights in shining armor
winning damsels in distress. Sadly, there are no dragons
left to fight on this world.
In a sense, however, all SCA members are.incurably in
love with the Age of Chivalry. A member gets to choose
his or her own name, title, family history, etc. -- the only
limit being that one cannot be named after a real person
or fictionalized character without permission, which is
slightly difficult in the former case. For those Tolkien,
Moorcock, or other fantasy readers, this is your chance to
become a part of the fantasy you always hoped you could
act out but never dared.
If you insist on being a fighting man or woman,armor
is something of a problem. There are strict rules and
regulations as to what one can wear or must wear, set by
the SCA higher echelons. To engage the Black Knight, I
had to don armor which barely fit, a helm which almost
tore off my ears, hockey gloves for fist barding, elbow
pads‘ which constantly fell off, and a leather knee pad
which really was meant to be a thigh pad. The only
advantages my opponent had were superior training,
physique, and armor.. I won't bore you with the trivial
details of how the fight progressed: suffice it to say that I
am burning with desire to avenge my honor...
Therefore, if you can peel yourself away from studying
for a knight, come an,d see the SCA on _either the
Freshmen Quad or the field in front of Garland. Lose
yourself to a time of honour and chivalry, of jousting and
jesting, of good fun.

With the start of the new academic year, Associate Professor of Political Science Ric Pfeffer once more occupies the forefront of
campus concerns. Though Pfeffer is perhaps best known for his Marxist leanings, ideology is not the issue at this time. Nor, in fact, is the
Political Science Department,s decision not to award him the tenured position of full professor. Instead, the issue at hand is the Academic
Council,s refusal to appoint an ad hoc committee to review Pfeffer,s case more thouroughly.
It is a fundamental tenet of the American and all other civilized systems ofjurisprudence that one is entitled to appeal a court decision
he deems injust. Yet the Academic Council has denied Professor Pfeffer this right by rejecting his plea for an ad hoc committee
investigation. Thus, if Pfeffer was indeed the victim of bias and antagonism within his department, the Council has eliminated the
possibility of exoneration.
Further evaluation of Pfeffer's candidacy for tenure, then, is not simply a professional question, but .a moral one as well. The
controversy over Pfeffer's scholarship has not been conclusively resolved, and in the interests of fairness, deeper consideration of the
matter becomes imperative. We of the Student Council support an ad hoc committee investigation of Professor Pfeffer's record.
